title: Gently rounded font recommendation?
content:
So, I'm launching my personal portfolio site, and I'm currently titling with a free font called [Alte Haas Grotesk](http://web.archive.org/web/20150419005701/http:/www.dafont.com/alte-haas-grotesk.font). I probably don't even need to point out that it's ... er ... quite Helvetica-inspired.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150419005701im_/http:/typophile.com/files/altehaasgrotesk_5643.jpg)

I'd love to buy a sans-serif font with a similarly gentle rounding aspect (not looking for anything as direct as [Helvetica Rounded](http://web.archive.org/web/20150419005701/http:/www.linotype.com/13208/helveticaroundedbold-font.html)).

I shouldn't mention my budget for this purchase isn't too liberal, so the more affordable the recommendation, the better.

Thanks in advance for your suggestions!
author: smrvl

comments.content:
Hi David,

rather contemporary (actually brand-new!): [FF Unit Rounded](http://web.archive.org/web/20150419005701/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/fontfont/ff_unit_rounded_ot/). (You can test the bold weight [for free](http://web.archive.org/web/20150419005701/http:/www.fontshop.com/freefonts/), btw)

Rather old-school: [Bloc](http://web.archive.org/web/20150419005701/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/paratype/bloc_extra_condensed_ot/)

F

Good links, all! TDF, I think you've come closest (thus far) to what I'm looking for ... I actually like Mustardo even better than Ketchupa. I suppose I'm a sucker for a two-story a / single-story g system in a basic sans-serif.

These are really good directions. If anyone else cares to share, I'd love more suggestions! Thanks!

[Houschka Alternate](http://web.archive.org/web/20150419005701/http:/www.type.co.uk/index.php?p=a_to_z_listing&let=*&id=7432), although it's not really noticeable at that size.

Nick Cooke
